document.masterDocTitle: New and little known predatory katydids from Mascarene islands (Ensifera: Meconematinae and Hexacentrinae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: New and little known predatory katydids from Mascarene islands (Ensifera: Meconematinae and Hexacentrinae)

Male. Wings. Left FW with 46–51 (average: 48 ) lamellar teeth. Terminalia. Paraproct. With a long external tooth on the basis, distinctly spatulate distally (
Fig. 20
). Cerci. With a minute ventral basal tooth; triangular in shape (in side view), the top angle of the triangle distinctly before the middle of the cerci (
Fig. 19
). Genitalia. Epiphallus cephalic lobe in side view moderately inflated, in the continuation of the neck curvature (
Fig. 21
; NB. the epiphallus illustration in Jin & Kevan is a ¾ view).
Body Head Pronotum Tibia Femora FW O
I II III I II III III
L L W L W H L L L L L L W L L

18.9 1.9 2.7 3.7 3.0 1.3 9.0 7.9 15.4 8.2 6.5 13.4 1.7 3.8 11.6 Bioacoustics.
Figs. 47–48
.
Paradecolya inexpectata
is singing by night hours in the undergrowth from near the ground to several meters. Males do not move while calling. The call pattern differs as a function of temperature. At temperatures above 18 °C, the call consists of long echemes (> 1 min) made of many syllables; at 19 °C, syllables are repeated at the rate of 9–10 syllables/s (syllable duration: 53–72 ms; intersyllable interval: 32–55 ms); echemes are seldom interrupted by short breaks (~ 250 ms) and are made of 16– 20 trains of waves (
Fig. 47
). At low temperatures ( 16 °C), the echeme consists in syllable triplets (syllable duration: 134–226 ms; inter-syllable interval: 53–67 ms) separated by
0.67– 2.10
s (
Fig. 48
). The first harmonic peaks above 22 kHz.

Distribution. This species is widely distributed in la Réunion , having a wide tolerance in rainfall (from 1 m /year in the dry forest (e.g. Grande Chaloupe) to up to 9 m /year in the most humid part of the island (e.g.

hauts de Mare Longue), and in temperature (mean monthly temperature ranging from 19 °C to 26 °C in Grande Chaloupe and from 10 °C to 18 °C in Piton d’Enchaing). Although mostly present on exotic-free areas, this species spills over these preserved spots and can be observed in neighbouring anthropized areas, particularly on the highest range of its distribution.

Biology. Adults of this species occur during most of the year but are more frequent at the end of the Austral summer. This species feeds on small insects; trigonidiine crickets seem to represent an important part of its food (pers. obs.). Females lay eggs late at night, in the undergrowth, in dead branches.
